awd_titl_txt: TWC: Option: Medium: Collaborative: Authenticated Ciphers
awd_abstract_narration:
OpenSSH reveals excerpts from encrypted login sessions. TLS (HTTPS) reveals encrypted PayPal account cookies. DTLS is no better. EAXprime allows instantaneous forgeries. RFID security has been broken again and again. All of these failures of confidentiality and integrity are failures of authenticated ciphers: algorithms that promise to encrypt and authenticate messages using a shared secret key.

It is easy to blame many of these security problems on a lack of education: much stronger authenticated ciphers have been in the literature for many years. However, in many cases these stronger authenticated ciphers fail to meet the performance requirements of the applications. Performance is exactly the motivation for RC4 in WEP; EAXprime in the "Smart Grid"; HB in RFID; and "IPsec" continuing to support unauthenticated encryption.

This project is building a new generation of authenticated ciphers that improve efficiency without compromising security and that improve security without compromising efficiency. This work spans seven main topics: more efficient ciphers; more efficient MACs; more efficient forgery rejection; improved protection against side channels; improved protection against misuse and bad luck; improved quantitative security; and improved security proofs. The ultimate objective is to obtain the best possible security subject to a variety of performance constraints specified by cryptographic users.

The high-security high-performance authenticated ciphers produced in this project will be directly and straightforwardly usable in cryptographic applications, avoiding the disasters in current applications and finally bringing secure secret-key cryptography from theory to practice.

por.por_cntn:
Cryptographic competitions have emerged as a commonly accepted way of developing new cryptographic standards. Performance of candidates in hardware and security of such implementations have always been very important evaluation factors, especially at the final stages of the competitions. This project started from determining hardware efficiency and resistance to side-channel attacks of existing authenticated cipher standards, such as AES-GCM and AES-CCM. The main focus of the project was the support for the ongoing Competition for Authenticated Encryption: Security, Applicability, and Robustness – CAESAR, started in 2013. Seven authenticated ciphers developed as a part of this competition, ACORN, AEGIS, ICEPOLE, Ketje, MORUS, Tiaoxin, and TriviA-ck, have been shown to consistently outperform the current American federal standard, AES-GCM, in terms of the throughput to area ratio, by at least a factor of five when implemented using four modern high-performance Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) families: Virtex-6, Virtex-7, Stratix IV, and Stratix V. Five of these ciphers advanced to Round 3 of the CAESAR competition. Three of the candidates, AEGIS, ICEPOLE, and MORUS, have been shown to outperform AES-GCM in terms of throughput by a factor of above 13.

This project’s support for the competition included the development of the

  • common hardware Application Programming Interface (API), used consistently in hardware implementations of all candidates
  • development package composed of the code shared among high-speed and lightweight implementations of multiple authenticated ciphers
  • implementer’s guide supporting mutually compatible and close to optimal implementations
  • high-speed implementations of AES-GCM, 19 Round 2 and 11 Round 3 CAESAR candidates, optimized for the maximum throughput to area ratio and made open-source for full transparency of their hardware evaluation
  • lightweight implementations of 5 Round 3 CAESAR candidates, optimized for the minimum area and power consumption, and extended with countermeasures against side-channel attacks
  • new hardware optimization tool, Minerva, for fair benchmarking of all candidates using modern FPGA families
  • novel experimental setup for benchmarking of cryptographic algorithms using microcontrollers, XXBX – eXtended eXternal Benchmarking eXtension
  • new features of FOBOS - Flexible, Opensource workBench fOr Side-channel analysis, supporting power analysis (t-test, Differential Power Analysis, and power measurements) of cryptographic algorithms implemented using FPGA devices
  • on-line, interactive database, containing all FPGA results of the CAESAR hardware benchmarking, arranged in the way supporting ranking of candidates using various performance and cost criteria.

One of the major accomplishments of the project was the development of a novel design and benchmarking methodology, based on the use of High-Level Synthesis (HLS) tools. This methodology has been shown to offer a great potential to facilitate hardware development and benchmarking at all stages of cryptographic contests. A case study based on AES-GCM & 13 Round 3 CAESAR candidates demonstrated correct ranking of the majority of candidates using all major performance metrics. Additionally, HLS was successfully used to detect several suboptimal manual implementations of authenticated ciphers in hardware. In the future, our methodology is likely to lead to substantial progress in the general area of computer-aided design of digital systems, by being capable of turning a reference software implementation of an arbitrary algorithm, written in a high-level programming language, into an optimally parallelized hardware implementation.

Threshold implementations have been shown to be an effective method of protection against side channel attacks, at the expense of increased area and reduced throughput, but, typically, without significantly affecting the initial ranking of the candidates, based on the features of unprotected implementations.

The results of the project have been widely disseminated at crypto and FPGA conferences, in journals, and using a one-stop website (https://cryptography.gmu.edu/athena/index.php?id=CAESAR).

Two Ph.D. and two Master’s theses have been completed and defended within the duration of this project. Two additional Ph.D. theses have been substantially advanced. The evaluation of CAESAR candidates has been incorporated into several graduate courses.

The tools developed or enhanced as a result of this project, as well as the overall design and benchmarking methodologies will have an impact far beyond the CAESAR competition. They lay the foundation for implementing, benchmarking, and securing other types of algorithms, such as submissions to the NIST Post-Quantum Cryptography standardization process.

Authenticated ciphers with extended resistance to misuse and side-channel analysis, developed and analyzed in this project, will allow for a ubiquitous use of strong cryptography for the protection of data in modern communication and computer systems, including the Internet of Things and Cloud Computing. The newly developed and thoroughly analyzed ciphers will become prime candidates for future government, banking, and commercial standards. Future implementations of the emerging standards are likely to be based, at least partially, on numerous open-source implementations developed as a part of this project. The outcomes of the project will increase the confidentiality and integrity of business and personal communications in the United States and beyond. An increased protection against cyber-attacks by rogue states, criminal organizations, and individual hackers will become easier to accomplish without sacrificing performance or ease of use.
